articles.headline: For Financial Advice, Arriving at the Right Dosage
articles.snippet: People who need a little assistance have a number of inexpensive options. For those who want more guidance, the equivalent of a physical trainer is also available.
articles.abstract: People who need a little assistance have a number of inexpensive options. For those who want more guidance, the equivalent of a physical trainer is also available.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most everyone needs financial advice. The big question is how much.

articles.headline: Narrow Senate Race Unnerves Democrats on Health Care
articles.snippet: A Republican victory in Massachusetts could fracture the Democratic coalition behind health legislation, putting its approval in jeopardy.
articles.abstract: A Republican victory in Massachusetts could fracture the Democratic coalition behind health legislation, putting its approval in jeopardy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With their party’s candidate struggling in Massachusetts in a race for what should be the safest of Senate seats, Congressional Democrats are growing increasingly unnerved about the political consequences of the health care overhaul even as their leadership closes in on a final agreement.

articles.headline: Scaling the Digital Wall in China
articles.snippet: Internet users in China are finding myriad ways to get around government blockades.
articles.abstract: Internet users in China are finding myriad ways to get around government blockades.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Great Firewall of China is hardly impregnable.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and David Barboza

articles.headline: For the Trapped, Rescue Is but the First Hurdle
articles.snippet: The fate of one man and the struggles of his rescuers reflect the complications of the aid effort in Haiti.
articles.abstract: The fate of one man and the struggles of his rescuers reflect the complications of the aid effort in Haiti.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Herby Amel’s father dug through the collapsed college building first, pulling out a body so he could reach his son, trapped 20 feet into the pile. But when a rescue team from Miami arrived early Friday morning, Herby’s left ankle remained pinned under a fallen beam.

articles.headline: Hershey Said to Be Closer to an Offer for Cadbury
articles.snippet: Hershey is working with JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America to raise at least $10 billion for a bid, people briefed on the matter said.
articles.abstract: Hershey is working with JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America to raise at least $10 billion for a bid, people briefed on the matter said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hershey edged closer to a bid for Cadbury of Britain on Friday, people briefed on the matter said. The move comes just days before Kraft is set to disclose its final offer for the confectioner.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: A Gangland Bus Tour, With Lunch and a Waiver
articles.snippet: LA Gang Tours, which is making its debut on Saturday, promises to take tourists to “high-profile gang areas.”
articles.abstract: LA Gang Tours, which is making its debut on Saturday, promises to take tourists to “high-profile gang areas.”
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The tour organizer received assurances, he says, from four gangs that they would not harass the bus when it passed through their turf. Paying customers must sign releases warning of potential danger. And after careful consideration, it was decided not to have residents shoot water guns at the bus and sell “I Got Shot in South Central” T-shirts.

articles.headline: China, Where U.S. Internet Companies Often Fail
articles.snippet: Before Google’s difficulties in China, Yahoo, eBay and MySpace were outsmarted by local companies and limited by government restrictions.
articles.abstract: Before Google’s difficulties in China, Yahoo, eBay and MySpace were outsmarted by local companies and limited by government restrictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  If Google pulls out of China because of frustration with government restrictions, it will not be the first time an American Internet giant has retreated from the country.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Brad Stone

articles.headline: Officials Strain to Distribute Aid to Haiti as Violence Rises
articles.snippet: A sprawling assembly of international officials and aid workers struggled to fix a troubled relief effort.
articles.abstract: A sprawling assembly of international officials and aid workers struggled to fix a troubled relief effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  As the focus on Saturday turned away from Haitians lost to those trying to survive, a sprawling assembly of international officials and aid workers struggled to fix a troubled relief effort after Tuesday’s devastating earthquake.
articles.byline: By Ginger Thompson and Damien Cave

articles.headline: Morgan Stanley Tries on a New Psyche
articles.snippet: James P. Gorman wants to build a steadier, more diversified Morgan Stanley, and avoid risky megatrades.
articles.abstract: James P. Gorman wants to build a steadier, more diversified Morgan Stanley, and avoid risky megatrades.
articles.lead_paragraph: JAMES P. GORMAN, a 6-foot-2 Australian, recently took up boxing lessons, in keeping with some of the trappings of his Midtown Manhattan office. On one wall, opposite an inspirational poem by Rudyard Kipling (“The Thousandth Man”), hangs a photograph of Elvis Presley sparring with Muhammad Ali.

articles.headline: Massachusetts Race Tests Staying Power of Democrats
articles.snippet: There may be no better place to measure the fortunes of the Democratic Party than in the race for the Senate seat that was Edward M. Kennedy’s.
articles.abstract: There may be no better place to measure the fortunes of the Democratic Party than in the race for the Senate seat that was Edward M. Kennedy’s.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON  There may be no better place to measure the shifting fortunes of President Obama and the Democratic Party than in the race being fought here this weekend for the Senate seat that had been held by Edward M. Kennedy.

articles.headline: NBC’s Slide to Troubled Nightly Punch Line
articles.snippet: NBC has been brought down by missteps that have made its prime-time lineup a loser and turned its late schedule into a media circus.
articles.abstract: NBC has been brought down by missteps that have made its prime-time lineup a loser and turned its late schedule into a media circus.
articles.lead_paragraph: At its height, NBC was the very model of what a television network should be. With iconic programming, enviable ratings and spectacular business success, the peacock network delivered plenty of laughs along the way with “The Cosby Show,” “Seinfeld” and “Friends.”

articles.headline: Buying Landmarks? Easy. Keeping Them? Maybe Not.
articles.snippet: At properties in Chicago, New York and elsewhere, Jerry and Rob Speyer of Tishman Speyer Properties are dealing with the fallout of a deflated real estate market.
articles.abstract: At properties in Chicago, New York and elsewhere, Jerry and Rob Speyer of Tishman Speyer Properties are dealing with the fallout of a deflated real estate market.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT seemed a great idea at the time. In June 2007, Jerry I. Speyer and his son Rob bought six buildings in Chicago, making them one of the largest commercial landlords in the city.

articles.headline: Credit Cards and Reluctant Regulators
articles.snippet: If credit card issuers try to find ways around new rules on fees, how well would a federal agency enforce them?
articles.abstract: If credit card issuers try to find ways around new rules on fees, how well would a federal agency enforce them?
articles.lead_paragraph: ANYONE wondering how consumer rights might be faring in the Washington debate over financial regulatory reform has a lot to consider theses days.

articles.headline: Forget Gum. Walking and Using Phone Is Risky.
articles.snippet: Cellphones make pedestrians inattentive, and emergency room records show the results.
articles.abstract: Cellphones make pedestrians inattentive, and emergency room records show the results.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  On the day of the collision last month, visibility was good. The sidewalk was not under repair. As she walked, Tiffany Briggs, 25, was talking to her grandmother on her cellphone, lost in conversation.

articles.headline: Lonely Trek to Radicalism for Terror Suspect
articles.snippet: Behind Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab’s journey from gifted student to terrorism suspect was a struggle between an investment in this life and a longing for the next.
articles.abstract: Behind Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab’s journey from gifted student to terrorism suspect was a struggle between an investment in this life and a longing for the next.
articles.lead_paragraph: KADUNA, Nigeria  Well before Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab disappeared into the rugged mountains of Yemen with an ominous goodbye to his father  warning him that “this is the last time you are going to hear from me,” according to top Nigerian officials  the tensions between the two pious men had already begun to show.

articles.headline: Looting Flares Where Authority Breaks Down
articles.snippet: The impulses for theft were borne of desperation and the lack of food and water as well as the absence of law.
articles.abstract: The impulses for theft were borne of desperation and the lack of food and water as well as the absence of law.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Along the capital’s main commercial strip Saturday afternoon, dozens of armed men  some wielding machetes, others with sharpened pieces of wood  dodged from storefront to storefront, battering down doors and hauling away whatever they could carry: shoes, luggage, rolls of carpet.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Marc Lacey

articles.headline: In Senate Race, Massachusetts Bucks a Political Stereotype
articles.snippet: Swing voters have tipped the balance in recent elections, and could prove crucial again on Tuesday in the race for the late Edward M. Kennedy’s Senate seat.
articles.abstract: Swing voters have tipped the balance in recent elections, and could prove crucial again on Tuesday in the race for the late Edward M. Kennedy’s Senate seat.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARLBOROUGH, Mass.  Angela Grenham, 50, was raised a Massachusetts Democrat  “We had the crucifix and the J.F.K. sign,” she recalled  and voted for a Democrat for president as recently as 2000, when she supported Al Gore.

articles.headline: Companies Fight Endless War Against Computer Attacks
articles.snippet: The intrusion into Google’s computers and related attacks point to the rising sophistication of such assaults and the vulnerability of even the best defenses.
articles.abstract: The intrusion into Google’s computers and related attacks point to the rising sophistication of such assaults and the vulnerability of even the best defenses.
articles.lead_paragraph: The recent computer attacks on the mighty Google left every corporate network in the world looking a little less safe.

articles.headline: It’s Not Jay or Conan. It’s Us.
articles.snippet: Don’t blame the late-night hosts for falling ratings. The Internet and cable television have made much of network television disappear into a thicket.
articles.abstract: Don’t blame the late-night hosts for falling ratings. The Internet and cable television have made much of network television disappear into a thicket.
articles.lead_paragraph: The other night, my daughter and I watched Jay Leno, talking about him and his soon-to-be-canceled show. We took in Conan O’Brien as well, dissecting the inside jokes and the implications of his walking away from “The Tonight Show.” As they did their thing, we talked about their performing styles, demographic appeal and remarkable hair.

articles.headline: Amid Rubble, Seeking a Refuge in Faith
articles.snippet: With many churches flattened, the faithful gathered for solace on the rubble-filled streets on Sunday.
articles.abstract: With many churches flattened, the faithful gathered for solace on the rubble-filled streets on Sunday.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Five days after Haiti’s devastating earthquake, an evangelical pastor in a frayed polo shirt, his church crushed but his spirit vibrant, sounded a siren to summon the newly homeless residents of a tent city to an urgent Sunday prayer service.

articles.headline: In Hollywood, Grappling With Studios’ Lost Clout
articles.snippet: With home video revenue in decline, movie studios, bastions of the golden age of film, now don’t seem to matter as much to the success of their parent companies.
articles.abstract: With home video revenue in decline, movie studios, bastions of the golden age of film, now don’t seem to matter as much to the success of their parent companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  A proposed sale of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the most powerful and lucrative studio during the golden age of film, drew only meager offers last week, and now Hollywood must confront a troubling question: Are movie studios becoming a financial footnote?
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Review of Jet Bomb Plot Shows More Missed Clues
articles.snippet: Officials cite lapses that were not disclosed in the declassified government report about what went wrong.
articles.abstract: Officials cite lapses that were not disclosed in the declassified government report about what went wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by  Eric Lipton, Eric Schmitt and Mark Mazzetti.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, Eric Schmitt and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Rescues Beat Dimming Odds in Haiti but Fall Short of Need
articles.snippet: Rescue workers pulled more people alive from the rubble as water and emergency aid deliveries improved.
articles.abstract: Rescue workers pulled more people alive from the rubble as water and emergency aid deliveries improved.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Despite dimming odds, rescue workers pulled more people alive from the rubble  including a 7-year-old girl who survived more than four days eating dried fruit rolls in the supermarket that collapsed around her  as water and emergency aid deliveries improved on Sunday, though not nearly enough to meet Haiti’s desperate need.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Deborah Sontag

articles.headline: Wall St. Weighs a Challenge to a Proposed Tax
articles.snippet: Wall Street’s main lobbying arm hired a litigator, who could argue that a tax would unfairly penalize big banks.
articles.abstract: Wall Street’s main lobbying arm hired a litigator, who could argue that a tax would unfairly penalize big banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s main lobbying arm has hired a top Supreme Court litigator to study a possible legal battle against a bank tax proposed by the Obama administration, on the theory that it would be unconstitutional, according to three industry officials briefed on the matter.

articles.headline: In Recall, a Role Model Stumbles
articles.snippet: Johnson & Johnson, historically adept at crisis management, lost its footing last week over a recall of several hundred batches of popular medicines, including Tylenol.
articles.abstract: Johnson & Johnson, historically adept at crisis management, lost its footing last week over a recall of several hundred batches of popular medicines, including Tylenol.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Harvard Business School teaches future executives the gold standard in brand crisis management. The model dictates that a company should communicate clearly with the public about a crisis, cooperate with government officials, swiftly begin its own investigation of a problem and, if necessary, quickly institute a product recall.

articles.headline: Law to Curb Lobbying Sends It Underground
articles.snippet: In light of strict new regulations, some policy advocates are choosing not to declare themselves as lobbyists.
articles.abstract: In light of strict new regulations, some policy advocates are choosing not to declare themselves as lobbyists.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Ellen Miller, co-founder of the Sunlight Foundation, has spent years arguing for rules to force more disclosure of how lobbyists and private interests shape public policy. Until recently, she herself registered as a lobbyist, too, publicly reporting her role in the group’s advocacy of even more reporting. Not anymore.

articles.headline: Kabul Attack Shows Resilience of Afghan Militants
articles.snippet: An assault was the latest in a series of audacious insurgent operations meant to shatter the calm of Kabul.
articles.abstract: An assault was the latest in a series of audacious insurgent operations meant to shatter the calm of Kabul.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  A team of militants launched a spectacular assault at the heart of the Afghan government on Monday, with two men detonating suicide bombs and the rest fighting to the death only 50 yards from the gates of the presidential palace.
